Generate a new acmap object

acmap.Rd

This function generates a new acmap object, the base object for storing map data in the Racmacs package.

acmap(...)

Arguments

table_name

Table name
table

Table of titer data
ag_names

Antigen names
ag_date

Antigen dates
ag_reference

Is antigen a reference virus
sr_names

Sera names
ag_shown

Antigen shown
ag_size

Antigen size
ag_cols_fill

Antigen fill color
ag_cols_outline

Antigen outline color
ag_outline_width

Antigen outline width
ag_rotation

Antigen rotation
ag_aspect

Antigen aspect
ag_shape

Antigen shape
ag_drawing_order

Antigen drawing order
sr_shown

Sera shown
sr_size

Sera size
sr_cols_fill

Sera fill color
sr_cols_outline

Sera outline color
sr_outline_width

Sera outline width
sr_rotation

Sera rotation
sr_aspect

Sera aspect
sr_shape

Sera shape
sr_drawing_order

Sera drawing order
ag_coords

Antigen coordinates
sr_coords

Sera coordinates
comment

Map comment
minimum_column_basis

Map minimum column bases
transformation

Map transformation
colbases

Map column bases
optimizations

A list of optimizations with appropriate attributes

Value

Returns the new acmap object

Details

The fundamental unit of the Racmacs package is the acmap object, short for Antigenic Cartography MAP. This object contains all the information about an antigenic map. You can read in a new acmap object from a file with the function read.acmap and create a new acmap object within an R session using the acmap function.

See also

See optimizeMap for generating new optimizations estimating antigen similarity from the acmap titer data.

Other functions to create and save acmap objects: read.acmap.cpp, read.acmap, save.acmap, save.coords, save.titerTable

Examples

# Read in an acmap object from a file
map_file_path <- system.file("extdata/h3map2004.ace", package = "Racmacs")
map <- read.acmap(map_file_path)

# Read in a table of titer data and make a new acmap file from it
titer_file_path <- system.file("extdata/h3map2004_hitable.csv", package = "Racmacs")
titer_data <- read.titerTable(titer_file_path)
map <- acmap.cpp(table = titer_data)
